utterance: AB: Yes. Hi everyone. I'm Ashley Baber. I am an associate professor at James Madison University in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. So I'm very interested in thinking about carbon dioxide hydrogenation from a model catalyst perspective up towards near ambient pressures.

utterance: VV: Maybe I'll start. Thank you. I'll pose I'll I guess I guess first first pose a question which is I think that might be useful to frame the discussion, which is what is a complete picture? I think that might be might be a good good one to sort of define very clearly. And in my mind, I'll give a first first pass which hopefully you will all agree, disagree with is, essentially, what are the what are the control variables, right? You have a particular catalyst, you have particular reaction conditions. So concentration of CO2, medium, electrolytes, etc. And then a range of different driving forces such as voltage. And then other sort of photon or or if you're thinking photocatalytic, then photon driven and maybe P photoelectro catalytic. So maybe those are combined. And so what we want to be able to say is, given control variables as well as driving forces, what will be the product distribution when product distribution of this reaction? That's sort of the highest order. And the second granularity would be that if you could understand exactly how that product was reached or or what were the what were the intermediate steps. So I think first might be a reasonable achievement even if that's done. The second would be obviously from a science perspective, second would be the more important achievement.

annotations.present new idea: "What is a complete picture?" is presented as a framing question to guide the discussion about universal principles for CO2 reduction.
annotations.ask clarifying question: VV asks "what is a complete picture?" to clarify the goals of the discussion and define what a comprehensive understanding of CO2 reduction would entail.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: VV defines "complete picture" in the context of CO2 reduction as understanding the control variables, driving forces, and resulting product distribution, as well as the intermediate steps involved.
annotations.propose decision: VV proposes focusing on defining "complete picture" as a starting point for the discussion.
annotations.expand on existing idea: VV expands on the initial question by proposing two levels of understanding a "complete picture": predicting product distribution based on control variables and driving forces, and understanding the intermediate reaction steps.

What are the different pathways and how do we pick a pathway to go get your particular product, right? So if you're given a whole bunch of possible trajectories, how do you take a reaction down a specific trajectory?

utterance: WS: Great. Maybe can build off of that and and slightly play devil's advocate because I think there's a lot of discussion for a long time in the field about CO2 reduction. One of the big questions is CO2 reduction to what product? And because there's upwards of 18 different products when we look at especially the talk

annotations.expand on existing idea: Wilson builds upon Venkat's idea of a 'complete picture' by pointing out the challenge of diverse product formation in CO2 reduction.

utterance: WS: Yesterday from the UK climate, a woman was, you know, we need big solutions, we need them now. So I think for me because there's two other sections that are looking at mechanistic CO2 reduction, we should look at a bit bigger picture. And I think one of the things we should consider is maybe CO2 reduction directly won't make every product that we want it to. Maybe we're not going to be able to make methanol, ethanol, propanol. And so, understanding selectivity, I think, is still something that's very interesting and fundamental, but you know, I think to focus that could be the selectivity of CO2 reduction versus hydrogen evolution as one major bifurcation. And then, you know, what CO2 reduces to. I mean, my personal opinion is that at an industrial scale, electrochemical CO2 reduction at best will get us CO and formic acid, but I don't think at an industrial scale we're going to make any other product, and that's fine because I think the role that electrochemistry and electrochemical CO2 reduction can be making really stable robust precursors that can be converted by more, you know, advanced processes. So to me, you know, I think the discussion should be less about selectivity to kind of C2, C3, C4 products, but more this kind of intrinsic. One thing I think we all would agree, however we do this, water will be involved there somewhere and shutting off hydrogen evolution versus CO2 reduction as a main bottleneck. I think that could be something that is interesting for everyone.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Wilson builds upon Venkat's idea of a "complete picture" by suggesting that the focus should be broader than just product distribution and include the bigger picture of industrial scale production and the role of CO2 reduction in creating precursors for further processing.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Wilson supports his argument for a broader focus by mentioning a talk from the UK climate conference emphasizing the need for big solutions now and the existence of other sections focused on mechanistic CO2 reduction.
annotations.propose decision: Wilson proposes that the discussion should focus less on selectivity to C2, C3, and C4 products and more on the intrinsic challenge of suppressing hydrogen evolution in favor of CO2 reduction.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: Wilson suggests that focusing solely on selectivity to a wide range of products might be too narrow a focus given the current state of the field and the urgent need for solutions.

utterance: SB: That's a great point. So, what is urgently required, right? We don't perhaps urgently need to make propanol, but we need to get a lot of CO2 out, right? utterance: VV: What is the maximum density that you could back these, I mean, the challenge with bio catalyst in general, right, is, is sort of the effective active site density. I mean, that's sort of the, the coverage at which reaction turnovers are happening. So, and, and it may become like one in 100 or one in 1000 if it becomes bio, which, which then, what that means is the reactor then scales by 10x or 100x, right, for producing the same product. utterance: EM: I think though that, that proteins can actually achieve that level of efficiency. I'm not saying that everyone can, but, but part of, part of the beauty of these types of systems is that they tend to have fairly high turnover numbers or turnover frequencies.

utterance: PB: Ellen, I would, I would add to what Venkat is saying is that if I look at traditional large-scale processes, industry folks would generally use a time scale of your turnover. utterance: SB: Do you use like biological? Because I mean, you have very good product selectivity, right? So if initial steps are done electro catalytically, could you do then some fine chemical transformations with biological systems?

utterance: CM: One thing just to add to here is if you think about a biological system, basically you have a bunch of machinery, a protein, you have a bunch of machinery that's basically just dictating the local chemical microenvironment of the catalytic active center. Maybe I'm biased because this is what I work on, but you can take a molecular catalyst that you know does this like a, a, an N4 catalyst and put it in polymers that mimic a lot of this, which is cheaper. It mimics all of the delivery and you can get, and then you still have low site density, but you can build up layers of this on the surface. You can build vertically and you can get these three, basically 3D architectures of these polymer catalyst composites.
